item.title: End-to-end Development of Texas Inventionworks' Kiosk Website
item.description: Please Note: Some details of this project have been censored to honor confidentiality! ðŸ“Œ Project Scope Client: Texas Inventionworks Timeline: Full-time, 3 months My Role: Lead-UX Researcher, Lead-UX Designer, Lead-UX Engineer Team: 2-3 student student staff members Methods: User Personas, User Flows, Wireframes, Rapid Prototyping Tools: Figma, Agile Scrum, AWS, React ðŸ§ Background During the summer of 2020, I co-led the development of a website to automate and digitize the operational workflow of Texas Inventionworks (TIW) (The University of Texas at Austin’s engineering school’s Makerspace).

item.title: The Sun
item.description: Donâ€™t look into the sun They tell you as a child But itâ€™s so hard not to When consequences seem mild I stare up at through the oak tree A fluttering filter to the sky Every once in a while a leaf moves And then sun burns my eyes I do not panic I do not look away For in less than a second a leaf guards my gaze Whatâ€™s left is a pulsing blue dot

item.title: How I Used Machine Learning to Meet My Favorite Artist
item.description: Using Neural Style Transfer for R.F. Alvarez Paintings. Project Summary: Have you heard of DALLE? Not the artist… well… not exactly not an artist, but the AI model from OpenAI? For those of you unfamiliar with the artist reference, Salvador DalÃ­ was a mustached man who painted melting clocks and had a knack for turning everyday objects into surreal works of art. For those of you who don’t know about the AI model, DALLÂ·E is an AI model that can create any image you may dream based only on the words you give it- sorta like an artist on demand.

item.title: Blurred Lines
item.description: Are your virtual experiences creating simulated realities? Could you tell them apart from actuality? Are your virtual realities creating simulated experiences? And if that is the case, when does it become deleterious ? Could you explain, to me, the difference? I think the line is blurring for me. I think the line is blurring me. -z.z.

item.title: See Through
item.description:
Tell me why you like blue eyes. When you stare, who do you see? Because when you look into my eyes. I know you’re not looking at me.
To be fair, I like brown eyes. For reasons assumed the same. Because when I look into your eyes, All I can think of is their name. -z.z.

item.title: A Comprehensive Follow-Up Investigation of Employee Satisfaction Survey Results
item.description: Please Note: Many details of this project have been censored to honor confidentiality! ðŸ“Œ Project Scope Client: Company A Timeline: Part-time, 3 months My Role: UX Researcher Team: Senior Staff Member (assisted with group interview sessions) Methods: User Personas, Surveys, Focus Groups, Interviews Tools: Zoom, Google Docs ðŸ§ Background Employee engagement and satisfaction is a critical factor influencing productivity and organizational success. It is not without suprise that many companies conduct annual employee engagement surverys to gather longitudinal data about the workplace they are cultivating.

item.title: My Tiny Record Player
item.description: Background All my friends have record players- their homes are full of warm analog music and dusty wooden crates full of vinyl records. I love the ritual of sifting through the fraying sleeves, gently sliding the record out of its casing, placing it onto the record player, the hum of the motor beginning to turn, and hearing the warp as the needle hits drops. Dinner parties and hangouts have a certain jenosaiqua when envoloped in the warm static of physical music.

item.title: How I Used Machine Learning to Meet My Favorite Artist

For those of you unfamiliar with the artist reference, Salvador DalÃ­ was a mustached man who painted melting clocks and had a knack for turning everyday objects into surreal works of art. For those of you who don’t know about the AI model, DALLÂ·E is an AI model that can create any image you may dream based only on the words you give it- sorta like an artist on demand.

item.title: Soda Pop Lover
item.description: Soda pop lover, My sweet little treat I love the days we spend lazing in your sheets Savoring small sips of each other Itâ€™s hard not to cave in for just one more … and another I drown in your sparkling Carmel eyes Your bubbly voice whispering in my ears Your kiss tingles my insides with a delightful fizz You fill my body and brain with happiness Nothing could be better than this

item.title: Sentiment Analysis for Post-Approval Birth Control Review Pharmacovigilance
item.description: 1. Introduction While pharmaceutical birth control continues to be the most popular method of contraceptive in the United States, the proliferation of different formulations of these methods can make decisions regarding which to use difficult for individual persons (Kavanaugh & Jerman, 2018). Additionally, research has shown that there may be a tendency for providers to diminish or avoid disclosing adverse side effects of contraceptives, further hindering a comprehensive understanding of its efficacy (Stevens, 2018).

item.title: Computer-Aided Yoga
item.description: Introduction In my final semester of college, I had already completed all my course requirements, so I had the opportunity to enroll in some fun classes. I enrolled in Startitical Learning, Natural Language Processing, Advanced Regression Analysis, and Introduction to Yoga. Can you choose the item that doesn’t belong in this list? If you chose Yoga, you’re technically correct, however, I decided to merge my knowledge of Machine Learning and love for Yoga for my final project to creatively represent what Yoga means to me.

item.title: ANOVA Walkthrough
item.description: What is ANOVA? ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) falls under a category of techniques called inferential statistics which allow you to test hypotheses or assess if Analysis of Variance your sample is generalizablbe to a broader population. A one-way ANOVA is a technique that extends the independent two-sample t-test to multiple groups, enabling users to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between group population means. Why ANOVA? Say, for example, we want to find out which pre-workout snack lead to different mean mile times.

item.title: My first publication!
item.description: Here’s a link to the paper! Feel free to email me if you can’t access it and I will send you the pdf.

item.title: Naive Bayes Classification
item.description: For this week’s homework we are going explore one new classification technique: Naive Bayes In this post we are going to use a dataset of Melboburne housing to predict the housing type as one of three possible categories: ‘h’ house ‘u’ duplex ’t’ townhouse In addition to building our own Naive Bayes classifier, we are going to compare the performace of our classifier to the Gaussian Naive Bayes Classifier available in the scikit-learn library.

item.title: RNASeq Analysis of Arabadopsis thaliana
item.description: Analysis of RNASeq Data from Wild Type and Mutated Arabidopsis thaliana 0. Background In this report, we are primarily interested in understanding how the differences in gene expression between the light and dark conditions vary by gene in the primary gene ontology id GO:0006090. To this end, we will use DESeq to look for genes with significant interaction terms between genotype and timepoint. In interpreting the RNA-seq data set, you should note the following descriptions of the different sample genotypes:

item.title: Exploratory Data Analysis of SARS-CoV-2 Mutations
item.description: 0. Introduction COVID-19 is an infectionus disease caused by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). First identified in December of 2019, SARS-CoV-2 resulted in an ongoing pandemic effecting over 39 million people in 189 countries, but the WHO predicts that with asymptomatic cases, the number of infections may be closer to 800 million. Therapeutics for those suffering from COVID-19 include collecting and transplanting neautralizing antibodies from patients who have recoved from COVID-19.
